III. INVESTIGATION

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109
Section Program statement
Description (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written
program statement which specifically addresses all of the
following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents'
needs, implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of
residents.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Agency is not following their policies: Bedroom Policies, Team
meeting policies, or Incident Reporting Policies.
Investigation Interviews:
Allegation #1: Bedroom policies not being followed:
On 5/12/25, I spoke to Administrator 1 concerning the clutter and
large number of items in the youth’s bedrooms. Administrator 1
reported the youth are not to have the number of items in their
room as they currently do. Administrator 1 reported there was a
policy concerning the amount. Administrator 1 reported the youth
are to clean up their rooms as well.
The following interviews were completed face to face at the facility
on 5/21/25:
Youth A reported she is supposed to clean her room and
complete chores daily, but she does not always do so. Youth A
reported that if she doesn’t clean her room or do chores, staff do
not do anything about it.
Youth B reported they are to complete chores, including cleaning
their room. Youth B reported the staff may remove an activity if
cleaning doesn’t happen, but the youth don’t have to actually
clean their room.
Youth C reported they are to complete chores twice a day,
including their room. Youth C reported if youth refuse staff will
complete the chores for them.
Youth D reported they are to complete chores and clean their
room. Youth D reported they are not allowed to have all of the
items they have in their room, but staff do not do anything about it.
Staff allow them to get their items from the locked closet and don’t
2

ask for items in return, so youth have too many items in their
room. Youth D reported she is to have seven outfits in her room.
Youth D reported she has double that amount plus 12 pairs of
shoes and 12 stuffed animals and multiple books.
Youth E reported everyone has chores but staff do not make
them complete them. Youth E reported that staff will complete the
chores if they don’t do them. Youth E reported she is only
supposed to have seven outfits in her room, but she has more.
Youth E reported there are no consequences to not completing
chores.
Youth F refused to be interviewed.
Staff 1 reported youth are to complete chores but the youth refuse
to do them. Staff 1 reported if the youth don’t clean them then the
staff are to complete them. Staff 1 reported administration told
them they had to clean for the kids. Staff 1 reported he knows the
youth have too many items in their room, including clothing,
shoes, hygiene and random items. Staff 1 reported since he is
male, he doesn’t go into the female rooms. Staff 1 reported the
youth are only to have a small number of items and only staff can
obtain these items in the locked closet. Staff 1 reported staff are
supposed to make sure they have the allotted amount only. Staff 1
reported he was never given a directive to remove the excess
items in the room. Staff 1 reported they don’t remove the items
because the kids get angry if you ask them or would take their
items. Staff 1 reported there is a policy that male staff cannot go
into the female hallways so he doesn’t monitor their rooms.
The following interview was completed via telephone on
5/22/25:
Staff 2 reported that the youth do not complete their chores and
there are no consequences for this. Staff 2 reported the
administration pacifies the youth and will not allow consequences
to occur. Staff 2 reported whenever the staff want to consequence
the youth, they are to call the upper management first and ask
them if it is okay. Upper management will state no, because they
don’t want the youth to get angry and then possibly restrained.
Upper management was described as those above the unit
manager.
The following interviews were completed face to face at the
facility on 6/3/25:
3

Supervisor 1 reported youth are to complete chores and keep
their rooms clean. Supervisor 1 reported if they don’t clean, then
the youth are not to receive their weekly money. Supervisor 1 did
not know what the weekly money was used for. Supervisor 1
thought it was for when the youth left they would have money that
they had saved up in the program. Supervisor 1 reported there are
so many restrictions on the youth now, that immediate
consequences wouldn’t help anyway. Supervisor 1 reported the
youth are to have a certain number of items in their room, but they
do have more than allowed. Supervisor 1 reported that the youth
are not to have hygiene in their room but they do. Supervisor 1
reported there is a locked closet with the youth’s clothing in it. If
youth want different items of clothing, they are to exchange what
they do have for the items they would want. Supervisor 1 reported
this is not happening. Supervisor 1 reported they do not want to
“start issues with the kids” so they do not request the items back
or do room sweeps to ensure they have the appropriate items in
their rooms.
Supervisor 2 reported the youth are to complete chores but they
do not always complete them. Supervisor 2 reported there was not
a consequence for not completing them. Supervisor 2 reported the
youth are to have a certain number of items in their room, but staff
give them too many. Supervisor 2 reported there is a locked closet
where the items are at. Supervisor 2 reported the youth are to
exchange the items they have for the items they would like.
Supervisor 2 reported staff are providing items without gathering
the old. Supervisor 2 reported there are multiple staff who have
access to this closet, including the youth’s therapist. The youth will
manipulate and ask different staff through the day to get items.
Supervisor 2 reported there is not a system in place to track this.
Supervisor 2 reported they have discussed the youth’s items in
their rooms, but “the kids do not want us touching their stuff. I
can’t take their stuff from them. We can only talk to them.”
Supervisor 2 reported the youth will get upset if you take their
items.
Staff 3 reported that youth are not allowed to have the items they
have in their room, Staff 3 reported youth manipulate staff by
asking multiple staff for items. Staff 3 reported she does not know
why they did not take the extra items back from the youth in their
room. Staff 3 reported if the youth do not complete their chores,
then the staff complete them. Staff 3 reported there are no
consequences to not completing chores.
4

Supervisor 3 reported that youth are to complete chores but can
refuse to complete them. If they refuse, then staff have to
complete the chores for them. Supervisor 3 reported there are no
consequences when youth do not complete chores. They will
receive a “check” and if they get so many then a nighttime activity
may be taken away.
Staff 4 reported youth are to complete chores but they refuse to
do so. Staff 4 reported there are no consequences for the youth.
Youth will get a “check” which means they will not get “dollars” for
that activity. Staff 4 did not know what the dollars were and did not
know when the youth received them. Staff 4 reported staff give the
youth too many items for their room. Staff 4 reported the staff do
not enforce the rules because they don’t want to “get into it” with
the kids.
Observation:
I walked into numerous bedrooms. Bedrooms were cluttered with
clothing, stuffed animals, numerous shoes (one bedroom had over
9 pairs of shoes), stacked books (one bedroom had over 30
books), blankets, hygiene products, and garbage bags filled with
items, tote bags filled with items, closed suitcase boxes with items
in it. Some rooms had multiple bags and closed containers with
items piled in them. Some rooms had empty glass cups, written
signs with profanity on it, and garbage (empty snack bags, empty
cups, rolled up papers on the ground, spoons, empty wrappers).
The rooms were unkempt and in disarray.
Documents Reviewed:
• Items Allowed in Client Bedrooms (document): 9 outfits,
4 pairs of shoes, 3 pajama gowns, 1 journal, 5 books, 1
picture frame, 3 stuffed animals 1 drinking cup, 3 hair ties.
Any additional items…will be placed in your personals until
you leave the program.
• Staff and Client Interaction Policy:
o When making room checks, respect the client’s
privacy. A male staff member should never make
visual checks of residential client’s bedroom or
bathroom area.
Allegation #2 Staff are not attending team meetings
Staff 1 reported he does not go to team meetings. They have
monthly unit meetings, and he just asks other staff what they
talked about. Staff 1 reported he has not received discipline for
this.
5

Staff 2 reported she goes to staff meetings once a month and
they discuss policies for the building. Staff 2 reported they don’t
discuss how to intervene to uphold those policies.
Supervisor 1 reported they have team meetings with staff.
Supervisor 1 reported the staff are supposed to attend but if they
don’t they receive the agenda in an email. Supervisor 1 reported
they do not discuss group dynamics or specific goals of youth in
the team meeting.
Supervisor 2 reported team meetings are mandatory but due to
schedules not everyone can come. Supervisor 2 reported they
also have the option for staff to attend via video conference as
well. Supervisor 2 reported the team meeting minutes are up in
the office after the meeting for staff to review. Supervisor 2
reported they don’t have a system to know if everyone has
received the minutes if they didn’t show up. Supervisor 2 reported
they did have “Pre a Post meetings” which are meeting completed
intermittently in the month based on dynamics of the youth.
Supervisor 2 reported this would be done before a shift but it is not
documented anywhere. The “Pre a Post meetings” were described
as staff discussing any issues within the group before their shift
started.
Supervisor 3 reported team meetings are monthly and mandatory
but not everyone comes to the meetings. Supervisor 2 reported
staff can come via video conference, but they do not always do
that either. Supervisor 3 reported that one time the whole day shift
didn’t come to the meeting. Supervisor 3 reported there is no
discipline for staff that don’t show up. Supervisor 3 reported they
used to have “pre” and “post” meetings in between the monthly
meeting but they haven’t had those lately. Supervisor 3 reported
when staff miss she will try to “catch” them by talking to them or
emailing them.
Staff 5 reported that she does not attend all the team meetings.
Staff 5 reported there may be follow up meetings for staff that
don’t attend via zoom. Staff 5 reported there are no consequences
for failing to attend team meetings. Staff 5 reported they do not
discuss interventions for staff to use with the youth. Staff 5
reported they (the staff) will debrief each other on what happened
the night before during shift changes.
Staff 3 reported she sometimes goes to team meetings in person
and sometimes on a “teams” call. Staff 3 reported she thinks staff
6

get written up for not going but hasn’t been written up herself.
Staff 3 reported that supervisors will inform staff of the details of
the meeting if they miss. Staff 3 reported there are minutes of the
meeting for staff to look at, but there is not a formal way to know
that all staff have received the minutes.
Documents Reviewed:
• Youth Coach Position Description (Staff): Attends and
participates in group sessions, in service training, and all
staff meetings.
• Employee Behavior Policy: Enhance their job-related
knowledge and skills by attending and participating in all
staff training offered on and off campus.
Allegation #3:
Interviews:
Youth D was interviewed on 5/21/25. During her interview she
reported that she was threatening and pushing staff and youth.
She reported this occurred on 5/19/25. Due to her behavior police
had come to the agency. Youth D reported she was arrested, and
the police officer pushed her and shoved her.
Administrator reported there was not an incident report
completed for the incident on 5/19/25.
Documents Reviewed:
• Incident Report Policy: Vista Maria must document all
critical incidents and any irregular occurrences or events
that are inconsistent with routine operations.
Analysis
Allegation #1:
The agency is non-compliant with this rule. The youth’s bedrooms
are cluttered and unsafe. All staff interviewed reported there are
too many items in the room and multiple staff and supervisors
reported they are unable to do anything about this. The agency
has a document outlining what is permitted in a room and they do
not follow this document.
Technical Assistance:
Staff 1 reported he is not allowed to go into the female hallways.
All staff are to provide for the safety and security of youth, as well
7

as ensure youth are following policies. Policy does not state that
the males cannot enter into the hallways, but it does state they
can’t look into the bathroom or bedrooms. The hallways include
bedrooms and bathrooms. If males are not able to complete visual
looks of the bathroom and bedrooms, then this is creating a safety
issue and either males cannot work with females or the policy
needs to be altered to allow staff of any sex to supervise youth.
The agency can train the staff on appropriate boundaries and
ensure they have awareness from other staff if there are more
high-risk situations.
It would benefit the agency to have a system to obtain clothing
and personal hygiene. It would also benefit the agency to train
staff on structure, rules and interventions. Room sweeps and
upholding the rules are within the staff and supervisors’
parameters and clear consequences and actions to restore
compliance should be sought and discussed. Policies reviewed
did not outline specific interventions to use. Policies did not
provide procedures outlining how staff are to intervene.
The agency would benefit from looking into their behavior
management award and consequence system. The
consequences are not immediate and do not allow natural
consequences to take place. Staff are completing youth chores.
This disempowers the staff and places no responsibility on the
youth to complete their own tasks or take pride in the place they
live.
Consultation:
Staff and Supervisors feel disempowered and are afraid of youth
responses to their interventions. Staff feel that they are not
“allowed” to consequent or take items from youth because this
may cause youth to be angry. If supervisors on the unit are afraid
to redirect and challenge behaviors then either more intense
training and oversight of the unit supervisors need to be
established or different supervisors need to be placed in these
roles, that can fulfil the job responsibilities. It may also benefit the
agency to train staff on the definition of consequences in relation
to the restorative model approach used by the agency. The staff
appear to not be able to differentiate between punishment and
consequences.
Allegation #2:
The agency is not compliant with this rule. Staff 1, Staff 3, Staff 5
all reported they either do not attend unit meetings or are
8

inconsistent with attendance. Supervisor 1, Supervisor 2, and
Supervisor 3 reported that unit meetings are mandatory, but staff
do not always come to the meetings. The Youth Coach Position
Description outlines this as a task they are to complete. The
Employee Behavioral Policy outlines staff are to attend all
meetings.
The agency
Technical Assistance:
Staff are not attending unit meetings. Unit meetings are only once
a month. Supervisors are responsible for the culture of their unit. If
staff do not attend the unit meetings, then there should be a
formal way of addressing this. There also is to be a way where
staff receive the information they have missed. Unit Agenda
Minutes are not specific and do not provide necessary information
to understand the goals of the unit and each individual youth, nor
treatment interventions for the culture of the unit. This follow-up
should be formally done so that the team knows the plans and
treatment for the month. It is the agency’s responsibility that all
staff are well-informed and trained.
Consultation:
Unit meetings are held only once a month. Group culture changes
and individual needs change often. Goals for individual youth and
action steps to achieve those goals written in treatment plans can
be achieved much earlier than in a months’ time frame.
Scheduling therapeutic activities based on where the group is at
and where individuals are, takes communication from all treatment
partners, and should be done more often.
Weekly or biweekly unit meetings would help provide more
intense services. Youth could be discussed individually focusing
on their individual goals. Group dynamics and overall facility
conditions could also be incorporated.
Allegation #3:
The agency is non-compliant of this rule. The agency did not
complete an incident report for Youth D’s assaultive behavior or
police contact.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4112
Section Criminal history check, subject to requirements; staff
Description qualifications
(4) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the
following:
(a) Ability to perform duties of the position assigned.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff are offering youth items to fight each other.
Investigation Interviews:
The following interviews were completed face to face at the
facility on 5/21/25:
Youth A, Youth B, Youth C, Youth E, Youth G, Youth H, Youth
I, Staff 1, Staff 3, and Staff 4 all reported they have never heard
or saw staff offer youth food to fight other youth.
Staff 2 was interviewed via telephone on 5/22/25 and she
reported she never heard or saw staff offer food to youth to fight
other youth.
Youth D reported staff would state they would give us food if we
fought certain youth. Youth D was unable to say who the staff was
and who the youth were to be fought.
Youth F refused to be interviewed.
Supervisor 1, Supervisor 2, and Supervisor 3 were interviewed
face to face at the facility on 6/3/25 and all reported they have
never heard or saw staff offer youth food to fight other youth.
Analysis The agency is compliant with this rule. There is no evidence to
validate the allegations. Multiple youth, staff, and supervisors
reported they had never seen or heard this happen.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4125
Section Personal possessions; money; clothing; storage space
Description (1) A licensee shall have a written policy that designates all of
the following:
10

(a) The method used to safeguard residents' personal
possessions and money.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff are losing youth's property
Investigation Interviews:
The following interviews were completed face to face at the
facility on 5/21/25:
Youth A, Youth B, Youth C, Youth D, Youth G, and Youth H all
reported that staff have not lost their items.
Staff 1, Staff 2, Staff 3 and Staff 4 all reported they were
unaware of youth missing items.
Youth E reported when she moved from one unit to the next she
lost some of her items. Youth E reported she thinks that other
youth took her items. Youth E was unable to state what might
have been taken. Youth E did not report that staff lost her items.
Youth I reported someone threw an item out of hers. Youth I did
not know what the item was or who threw it out.
Supervisor 1, Supervisor 2, and Supervisor 3 were interviewed
face to face at the facility on 6/3/25 and all reported they were
unaware of youth missing items.
Analysis The agency is compliant with this rule. Multiple youth, staff, and
supervisors noted that staff have not lost youth items.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126
Section Sufficiency of staff.
Description (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of
administrative, supervisory, social service, direct care, and
other staff on duty to perform the prescribed functions
required by these administrative rules and in the agency's
program statement and to provide for the continual needs,
protection, and supervision of residents
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A reported staff are not intervening when youth become
physical. Youth B reported being attacked by another youth twice
without staff intervening.
11

Investigation Interviews:
The following interviews were completed face to face at the
facility on 5/21/25:
Youth A reported the ratio of staff to youth are 1:3. Youth A
reported there are not enough staff to stop fights from occurring.
Youth A reported when youth fight the staff that is with them will
attempt to push the youth apart but have to wait for other staff to
come help.
Youth B reported she has been physically attacked by other
peers, but staff did intervene and restrain them.
Youth C reported physical fights happen between youth. There
are times staff do attempt to separate but there are times they are
unable due to lack of staff present. Youth C reported they need at
least two staff to restrain. Youth C reported that the agency is not
allowed to restrain a youth without the second staff. Youth C
reported individual staff have intervened and they have been fired.
Youth C reported the agency was safer when those staff were
here because they stopped the fighting.
Youth D reported she has seen youth physically fight and staff not
intervene. Youth D reported they just “sit there.” Youth D reported
there are some staff that attempt to get in between the girls who
are fighting and push them away from each other.
Youth E reported she has seen youth physically fight each other.
Youth E reported staff do verbally say something, but do not
always physically intervene. Youth E reported there are some staff
that do get in between the youth fighting.
Youth F refused to be interviewed.
Youth H and Youth I both reported there are fights in the unit and
staff are not able to immediately break them up. Both reported the
staff will call for assistance and then when assistance comes,
break up the fight. Both reported in the meantime the youth are
fighting.
Staff 1 reported the ratio of staff to youth is 1:3. Staff 1 reported
there are a lot of “call offs,” which create a problem for ratio. Staff
1 reported he didn’t have to restrain so this is not an issue for him
and was unable to state if other staff were not intervening when
necessary.
12

Staff 2 was interviewed via telephone on 5/22/25. Staff 2 reported
they don’t have enough staff to always restrain the youth so they
have to wait until assistance comes. This may mean youth are
fighting until then. Some staff will step in and try to break it up.
The following interviews were completed at the facility on
6/3/25:
Supervisor 1 reported she has witnessed where youth are
fighting, and staff are not intervening. Supervisor 1 reported there
was a fight where one girl was being assaulted by two other girls
and the staff present did not intervene. Supervisor 1 could not
remember the name of the staff, but stated it was Youth G that
was hurt by the other girls. Supervisor 1 reported they have a staff
shortage so when youth are fighting, they will call out for a “clear”
and then any staff available will come to help. If they don’t have
staff, then they contact the campus and then wait for those staff to
arrive. Supervisor 1 reported they do have to wait until another
staff arrives because their restraint model trained needs two staff
to perform the restraint.
Supervisor 2 reported when youth are fighting they are unable to
restrain unless they have the proper number of staff (2) to perform
the restraint. When youth fight, they call for a “clear” and wait for
help to arrive. Supervisor 2 reported the youth are fighting in
between that time. Supervisor 2 reported that if she attempts to
get involved then the youth she isn’t grabbing may get hurt by the
one she is holding on to.
Supervisor 3 reported that if youth are fighting in the building,
they are to call for assistance. Supervisor 3 reported they need
minimally two staff to restrain a youth with their restraint model. If
the staff in the building do not come, then they are to call for
assistance from the campus. Supervisor 3 reported that youth are
fighting while waiting for help.
Staff 4 reported that when youth start to fight, they are to call for
assistance due to not having enough staff to restrain. Staff 4
reported there are times when they need multiple staff to help in
the situation. Staff 4 reported there are staff that will attempt to
break it up until help comes otherwise you have to wait while the
youth are attacking each other.
Documents Reviewed:
13

• Crisis Prevention Institution Manual (CPI):
o A Standing-Medium-Level Restriction requires two
staff members to hold a youth in between them.
o A Standing-High-Level Restriction requires two staff
members to hold a youth in between them.
o Defendable Decision Making moves are completed if
a youth attacks a staff; not youth assaulting youth.
• Program Statement: The policy outlines there is a 1:3 staff
to student ratio during waking hours.
Analysis The agency is non-compliant with this rule. Although the agency is
in the staff to student ratio outlined in their Program Statement,
they are unable to provide for the protection of the youth they are
supervising at that ratio. Both staff, youth, and supervisors all
acknowledged that youth were assaultive in their groups and staff
had to wait for additional staff to come to the unit to help separate
or restrain the youth. Sometimes they wait for additional staff that
were in the same building and other times they had to request
staff outside of their buildings. Either way, staff are unable to
intervene to provide safety due to lack of staffing. When there is a
need for more staff, based on the unit’s culture, the agency is to
make the necessary additions in staffing to provide that safety.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4149
Section Youth nutrition
Description (1) A licensee shall provide a minimum of 3 nutritious edible
meals daily unless medically contraindicated and
documented.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The food is toxic.
Investigation Interviews:
The following interviews were completed face to face at the
facility on 5/21/25:
**All individuals interviewed reported there are three meals a
day served as well as two snacks.
Youth G, Youth B, Youth E, reported the food is not seasoned
well, but it is cooked and not expired.
14

Youth A reported the food is moldy and rotten and snacks are
expired. Youth A could not report which specific food was moldy
or rotten. Youth A reported they receive fruit snacks, Chex mix
and chips for snacks.
Youth C reported the food tasted good. Youth C reported she
receives snacks as well and she likes them.
Youth D, Youth H, and Youth I reported the food is not seasoned
well and there was a time the chicken wasn’t cooked all the way
through. All reported the snacks are good. All youth reported the
staff ordered pizza that night instead of the dinner they received.
Staff 1 reported the food is comparable to lunch food at school. It
is not seasoned well though. Staff 1 reported he has never seen
food spoiled or rotten or expired. Staff 1 reported that youth
receive snacks as well.
Staff 2 was interviewed via telephone on 5/22/25. Staff 2 reported
the food does not taste good due to lack of seasoning, but there
has never been spoiled or rotten food.
The following interviews were completed at the facility on
6/3/25:
Supervisor 1, Supervisor 2, Supervisor 3, Staff 4, and Staff 5
reported they have never seen mold on food, rotten food, or
undercooked food.
Supervisor 1 reported she has never received a complaint about
the food.
Supervisor 2 reported the youth refuse to eat vegetables and
fruit.
Supervisor 2, Supervisor 3, and Staff 3 reported that if the youth
won’t eat the food, then they buy them pizza.
Documents Reviewed:
• Client Food Service Policy: …will meet the dietary needs
of our clients as established by the National Dietary
Association…weekly menus distributed to all units…
15

Analysis The agency is compliant with this rule. The youth are provided
with the right amount of food. Youth A was the only youth who
stated the food was moldy and rotten. There appears to be a time
that the food may have been undercooked, but Youth D, Youth H,
and Youth I all reported they received pizza that night. No one
complained of expired food except Youth A.
Consultation:
Staff and youth interviewed reported the food was not seasoned
well. It would be beneficial for the agency to look into the quality of
their food as well as providing condiments and seasoning in the
units if the food department does not season the food. The unit
also has a kitchen in the unit. It may be good for the youth to cook
their own meals with staff supervision as a life skill as well.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4150
Section Incident reporting
Description (4) When a resident's behavior results in contact with law
enforcement, the incident shall be reported to the parent/legal

• Client Behavior Management Policy: Behavior
management is tailored to the desired behavior. Effective
strategies require that: an inappropriate behavior is coupled
with a restorative task. ...are to be individualized, age
related, and short term.
Analysis The agency is found non-compliant with this rule. Staff and
supervisors were unable to provide interventions for the unit and
for individual youth. The things they did mention were, the inability
to provide consequences and to tell the youth to clean. Supervisor
1 and Supervisor 2 both reported they do not discuss individual
goals for youth or individual interventions for youth or group goals
or group interventions. Review of the unit meeting agenda also
confirms what the supervisors reported. Staff do not know the
positive intervention strategies to use and are not given direction
in what to practically do with each individual youth as noted in the
Client Behavior Management policy.
Technical Assistance:
There appears to be a disconnect in the treatment team.
Supervisor 2 reported that the therapist knows the goals and
interventions but not the unit team. The entire treatment team
should be aware of the goals in the treatment plans and the
interventions that are to be used to help the youth achieve those
goals. The Clinical team and staff and supervisors appear to not
have the same information to provide for the same outcome. In
order to provide trauma informed care, staff must understand the
trauma of their youth and be provided with goals and individual
interventions.
Consultation:
It would benefit the agency if the team meetings discussed
individual youth specifically their goals and action steps and
interventions that staff are to complete during school and
residential time. These should be outlined in the team meeting so
all staff are aware of the interventions. It would be beneficial to log
these interventions in the unit logging and state the outcome of
using that intervention for further assessment. Staff then can be
consistent and all parts of the team are working on the same goals

with the youth, but in a different manner, based on their role. Unit
meetings can then discuss the interventions used and what
worked well and what did not. The team can adjust as needed.
This would provide the direction that appears to be lacking in the
units.
Conclusion Violation Established

Section Facility and premises maintenance
Description (1) A facility and premises shall be maintained in a clean,

Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The facility is in deplorable conditions; broken and boarded up
windows and walls, flooring torn up, missing lights, trash
throughout the units, walls filthy, furniture missing cushions, and
sensory room not usable due to damaged equipment.
Investigation Observation:
I observed the facility on 5/21/25 and 6/3/25. On both occasions
there were broken and boarded up walls in the living space, the
23

bedrooms, and bathroom. In one bedroom, the tile floor was torn
up in front of the window.
I walked into numerous bedrooms. Bedrooms were cluttered with
clothing, stuffed animals, numerous shoes (one bedroom had over
9 pairs of shoes), stacked books (one bedroom had over 30
books), blankets, hygiene products, and garbage bags filled with
items, tote bags filled with items, closed suitcase boxes with items
in it. Some rooms had multiple bags and closed containers with
items piled in them. Some rooms had empty glass cups, written
signs with profanity on it, and garbage (empty snack bags, empty
cups, rolled up papers on the ground, spoons, empty wrappers).
Rooms were upswept, cluttered, and needed cleaned and
decluttered. The rooms were unkempt and in disarray. Both
bathrooms used by the unit were cluttered with towels and
hygiene items on the floors, and garbage overflowing.
I viewed the sensory room. It was in good condition, but it was not
used due to the behaviors of the youth.
The main area couches did have cushions on them.
All lights worked in the unit.
Documentation Reviewed:
• Standard Cleaning Policy: All staff must follow cleaning
procedures as recommended by the Center for Disease
Control….tie trash liners in waste containers and remove
them…spot wipe walls, doors furniture…mop or power
scrub floors and shower areas…sweep all floors and
shower areas daily…vacuum all furniture and carpet…no
visible soils, streaks on floors, doors, counters and other
hard surfaces…
• Program Statement: The agency provides services to
individuals with mental health needs…with a variety of
psychiatric needs.
Analysis The agency is non-compliant with this rule. The facility is not clean
or comfortable. Due to the clutter and unkempt areas, the facility
conditions make it unsafe for youth to reside. The population in
the unit are youth with a variety of mental health issues and
psychiatric needs. The conditions of the rooms allow for youth to
hide dangerous items to hurt themselves and others. The physical
environment of the facility is unsafe for the youth they provide care
for.
24

Technical Assistance:
The policy outlines for staff to complete the cleaning in the units.
The policy does not outline if staff are completing this while they
are supervising youth or after their shifts. If they are completing
this while on their shift, then the policy needs to document who is
supervising the youth, while the cleaning is occurring. The policy
does not outline who is monitoring this cleaning or documenting
this cleaning. This should be a part of the procedure of the policy.
There is not a policy and procedure for youth cleaning the unit and
what chores they are to complete. This will need to be added.
Consultation:
It would benefit the agency to incorporate a policy where youth
clean their living space, kitchen space, and staff guide them in
doing it properly.
Conclusion Violation Established
